_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response:

Wynnewood Refining Company (WRC) is required to follow the Process Safety Management Program under OSHA, and as such, has conducted audits in all the affected units.  WRC has also developed an emergency response plan following the National Response Plan Guidance Document to handle both on-site and off-site emergencies.

B.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:

Wynnewood Refining Company is a fully integrated petroleum refinery.  The main products are gasoline, diesel fuel, jet fuel, hydrocarbon solvents, liquefied petroleum gases and asphalts.  The covered processes considered for the RMP are as follows:

1)  HF Alkyl/Olefin Treater - The HF alky/olefin treater converts olefin and isobutane into gasoline using HF acid as a catalyst.  These units contain about 44,000 lbs of butane, 1-butene, 2-butene, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, isobutane, propane, and propylene.

2)  LPG Rack - This facility is an LPG storage, loading and unloading facility.  The LPG rack contains 24 tanks that typically contain about 3,000,000 lbs of butane, 1-butene, 2-butene, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, isobutane, propane, and propylene.

3)  Fluid Catalytic Cracker/Gas Con Unit - The FCC/GC unit processes gas oils into LPG?s, gasoline, distillate, and slurry oil.  The FCC/GC unit contains about 87,000 lbs of butane, 1-butene, 2-butene, 2-butene-cis, 2-butene-trans, isobutane, propane, and propylene.

4)  Crude Unit - The crude unit distillation processes crude oil into LPG?s, gasoline, diesel, naphtha, gas oils, and vacuum unit charge.  The crude unit contains about 18,000 lbs of propane, isobutane, butane and pentane.

5)  ROSE Unit - The ROSE unit extracts gas oils from vacuum asphalts using butane as a solvent.  The ROSE unit normally contains about 73,000 lbs of butane.

6)  Isomerization Unit - The isomeration unit converts pentane into isopentane.  This unit contains about 13,500 lbs of pentane and isopentane.

7)  Hydrocracker - The hydrocracker converts LCO and diesel type charge stocks into gasoline and lighter products.  This unit contains about 3,000 lbs of hydrogen, 500 lbs of hydrogen sulfide, and about 65,000 lbs of propane, isobutane, isopentane and heavier hydrocarbons.

8)  Platformer - The platformer converts low octane and straight chain naphtha into high-octane gasoline.  This unit contains about 1,500 lbs of hydrogen, and 15,000 lbs of propane, butane, and heavier hydrocarbons.

9)  Naphtha Unifiner - The naphtha unifiner removes sulfur from the naphtha charge to the platformer.  This unit contains about 1,500 lbs of hydrogen, 100 lbs of hydrogen sulfide, and 25,000 lbs of pentane and heavier hydrocarbons.

C.  The Worst-Case Scenarios and Alternative Scenarios:

The worst-case scenario for a toxic release was determined to be a release of 90,000 lbs of hydrofluoric acid from the settler vessel in the HF alkylation unit.  The distance to the endpoint, using the OSC analysis, was determined to be 12 miles.  No other toxics were found in the WRC facility that exceeded the threshold quantity.

The worst-case scenario for a flammable release was determined to be a release of 448,253 lbs of isobutane resulting from the failure of a bullet tank.  The distance to a 1-psi overpressure, using the OSC analysis, was determined to be 0.47 miles.

The alternate case scenario for a toxic release was determined to be the failure of a 4-inch valve on the settler vessel in the HF alkylation unit but with the deluge system knocking down the HF acid vapors.  The distance to endpoint was determined to be 0.43 miles.

The alternate case scenario for a flammable release was determined to be a release of 206,196 lbs of isobutane.  The distance to the 1-psi overpressure was determined to be 0.31 miles. 

D.  General Accidental Release Prevention Program & Chemical Prevention Steps:

WRC operators visually check their equipment to look for deterioration and signs of leakage.  If a p

roblem is found, the unit undergoes a thorough repair and inspection.  In addition, all process units undergo scheduled shutdown, cleaning and inspection, with repair of any problems found.  Employees, as well as emergency response personnel, including off-site doctors and hospital staffs, have been informed as to what chemicals WRC uses and procedures to minimize effects from exposures.

E.  Five Year Accident History:

During the past five years, this facility has had one release (see Section 6 of this RMP submittal) of a regulated substance under these rules that resulted in significant property damage on site and offsite evacuations.  The release did not result in any deaths or injuries on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.  At approximately 2:15 P.M. on May 12, 2006, there was an explosion and subsequent fire at the refinery's alkylation unit.  In addition to the fire, the event included an HF acid release.  The initial fire and HF acid release were controlled, but intermittent controlled releases occurred until May 21, 2006.  The total amount of HF released over the period was estimated at 4900 pounds.  The affected process unit is being repaired with restart expected by the end of 2006.

F.  Emergency Response Program:

WRC has prepared an emergency response plan using the National Response Center Integrated Contingency Plan Guidance Document to comply with a multitude of federal regulations.  This plan describes the response actions to be taken during on-site and off-site emergencies.

G.  Planned Changes to Improve Safety:

WRC investigates, thoroughly, all incidents under the OSHA and PSM regulations.  Any recommendations resulting from the investigations are implemented.
